Film Reviews

Review: The Secret Life of Walter Mitty

By James Bithell

Stiller's best directorial offering so far may have its flaws, but go with it and you will be rewarded with a film which is both heartfelt and visually stunning. Kate Barlow reviews

Review: The Class of '92

By James Bithell

Over the last two decades Manchester United have dominated English football and at the core of the team was the Class of '92. This documentary film is based on the emergence and rise of Fergie's fledglings. Lewis Hill reviews

Review: Nebraska

By James Bithell

Alexander Payne offers an unforgettable humorous but poignant take on a road movie, successfully avoiding sentimentality. Rosemary Collins reviews

Review: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug

Bilbo's second outing would make Tolkien dizzy. Alfie Packham reviews.

Review: The Railway Man

By James Bithell

Based on true events, The Railway Man is a powerful examination of the effects of war

Review: Frozen

By James Bithell

A charming new addition to Disney's repertoire with brilliant musical numbers. Niall Whitehead reviews

Review: In Fear

By James Bithell

Jeremy Lovering's debut is tense and well acted but fails to deliver anything ground-breaking. Amy Wong reviews

Review: The Counsellor

By Gracie Daw

Ridley Scott's new offering is stylish and atmospheric. Christoph Macdowall reviews

Review: Don Jon

By James Bithell

Gordon-Levitt's debut is sleak and smart but sometimes undercut by its own glossy production. Michael Brennan reviews

Review: The Hunger Games: Catching Fire

By James Bithell

The second film in the Hunger Games trilogy has darker undertones. Rosemary Collins reviews

Review: One Chance

By James Bithell

Feel-good biopic of Britain's Got Talent star Paul Potts fails to really pull any heartstrings. Maria Correa reviews

Review: Gravity

By James Bithell

Gravity will take you on an unbelievable journey. Fred Asquith reviews

Review: Philomena

By James Bithell

Stephen Frears' pensively measured film is no mere sleepy weepie. Alfie Packham reviews.

TV Review: Fresh Meat - series 3 episode 1

By James Bithell

Fresh Meat's season opener falls flat. Alfie Packham reviews.

Review: Thor: The Dark World

By James Bithell

Thor's sequel is no quiet, Loki affair. Niall Whitehead reviews

Review: Romeo & Juliet

By James Bithell

The cast are cute but Julian Fellowe's adap is too conservative. Afreen Hussain reviews

Review: The Fifth Estate

By James Bithell

Entertainment comes before authenticity in Bill Condon's WikiLeaks thriller. Jessica Burgess reviews.

Review: Captain Phillips

By James Bithell

A breathtaking Greengrass masterclass. James Lovatt reviews.

Review: Filth

By James Bithell

Jon S. Baird's adaptation is carried by its assured humour and fascinating characters. Alex Ferguson reviews.

Review: Le Week-End

By James Bithell

Le Week-End is more concerned with its characters' bumpy journey than their desirable destination. Katie Barlow reviews.

Review: Prisoners

By James Bithell

Expect coccyx bruises after 150 minutes on the edge of your seat at this multi-layered thriller. Alfie Packham reviews.

Review: Sunshine on Leith

By James Bithell

If you enjoyed <em>Mamma Mia</em>, go see this film. Fred Asquith reviews

Review: Blue Jasmine

By James Bithell

Cate Blanchett gives an Oscar-worthy performance in Woody Allen's latest. Rosemary Collins reviews.

Review: Insidious: Chapter 2

By James Bithell

James Wan follow-up to 2010's Insidious isn't life-changing, but if you're up for an hour of mindless 'cattle-prod cinema' then this is the film for you.

Review: R.I.P.D

By James Bithell

The morally ambiguous dead can make it to heaven by working for the Rest In Peace Department. The audience, however, doesn't get that option. 96 minutes of hell for us.

Review: The Great Beauty

By James Bithell

As its title would suggest, Paolo Sorrentino's The Great Beauty is a feast for the eyes and ears. Maddy Breen reviews.

Review: About Time

By James Bithell

Richard Curtis's latest is sparky and original but is let down by a lack of conflict. Rosemary Collins reviews.

Review: Ain't Them Bodies Saints

By James Bithell

Alluringly shot, the subtleties and simplicities of this vintage romantic thriller ensure a purely affective experience

Review: The Way, Way Back

By James Bithell

Nat Faxon and Jim Rash's second collaboration is a nostalgic and summery coming-of-age story without too sickly an aftertaste. Alfie Packham reviews.

Review: Upstream Color

By James Bithell

Shane Carruth's long awaited follow up to Primer is dense, bewildering and one of the few truly original films you'll see this year. James Tyas reviews.

By James Bithell

Stiller's best directorial offering so far may have its flaws, but go with it and you will be rewarded with a film which is both heartfelt and visually stunning. Kate Barlow reviews
